title: Why is it so hard for economists to get their forecasts right?
text:
The International Monetary Fund is likely to have everybody reaching for the tin hats next week when it publishes its latest World Economic Outlook forecasts.

Judging by Kristalina Georgieva’s maiden speech, the numbers are unlikely to be pretty. She’s already dropped hints over the weakest growth for nearly a decade and a “synchronised downturn”, not to mention the $19 trillion (£15 trillion) debt timebomb set to explode over the world’s eight biggest economies. It’s cheery stuff.

But before we climb into the bomb shelter, we should perhaps look at the IMF’s track record. Academics scanned through 26 years of the IMF’s WEO forecasts from 1990 to 2016 for the National Bureau of Economic Research...
